abstract.p: New York City Deputy Mayor Anthony Coles letter on Joyce Purnick's June 8 column that questions allocation of only $10 million for public school athletic fields; says column suggests that city neglects facilities for public schools; holds city provides Board of Education with $11 billion a year; says city government has no authority on how that money is spent; holds somewhere in all those billions there is money for more athletic fields, if only board considered them a priority

block.p: Re ''No Level Field for Athletes in Schools,'' by Joyce Purnick (Metro Matters column, June 8):
Re ''No Level Field for Athletes in Schools,'' by Joyce Purnick (Metro Matters column, June 8):

The column suggests that the city neglects athletic facilities for public schools. But the city provides the Board of Education with $11 billion a year. City Hall has no authority on how that money is spent. Somewhere in all those billions there is money for more athletic facilities, if only the board considered them a priority.

Ms. Purnick says the new Staten Island minor-league baseball complex will cost $71 million. She adds that this financing includes ''local improvements like a new esplanade.'' That's a funny way to characterize a complete renovation of the St. George Ferry Terminal; the construction of the National Lighthouse Museum and the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences; and new roads and commuter parking lots, among other things.
ANTHONY COLES Deputy Mayor for Planning, Education and Cultural Affairs New York, June 8, 2000
